an3.13:1.1.eng: “These three individuals are found in the world.

an3.13:1.3.eng: The hopeless, the hopeful, and the one who has done away with hope.

an3.13:1.4.eng: And what, mendicants, is a hopeless individual?

an3.13:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo nīce kule paccājāto hoti, caṇḍālakule vā venakule vā nesādakule vā rathakārakule vā pukkusakule vā dalidde appannapānabhojane kasiravuttike, yattha kasirena ghāsacchādo labbhati.
an3.13:1.5.eng: It’s when an individual is reborn in a low family—a family of corpse-workers, bamboo-workers, hunters, chariot-makers, or scavengers—poor, with little to eat or drink, where life is tough, and food and shelter are hard to find.

an3.13:1.6.pli: So ca hoti dubbaṇṇo duddasiko okoṭimako bavhābādho kāṇo vā kuṇī vā khañjo vā pakkhahato vā, na lābhī annassa pānassa vatthassa yānassa mālāgandhavilepanassa seyyāvasathapadīpeyyassa.
an3.13:1.6.eng: And they’re ugly, unsightly, deformed, sickly—one-eyed, crippled, lame, or half-paralyzed. They don’t get to have food, drink, clothes, and vehicles; garlands, fragrances, and makeup; or bed, house, and lighting.

an3.13:1.8.eng: ‘They say the aristocrats have anointed the aristocrat named so-and-so as king.’

an3.13:1.10.eng: ‘Oh, when will the aristocrats anoint me too as king?’

an3.13:1.11.eng: This is called a hopeless individual.

an3.13:2.1.eng: And what, mendicants, is a hopeful individual?

an3.13:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rañño khattiyassa muddhāvasittassa jeṭṭho putto hoti ābhiseko anabhisitto acalappatto.
an3.13:2.2.eng: It’s when someone is the eldest son of an anointed aristocratic king. He has not yet been anointed, but is eligible, and has been confirmed in the succession.

an3.13:2.4.eng: ‘They say that the aristocrats have anointed the aristocrat named so-and-so as king.’

an3.13:2.6.eng: ‘Oh, when will the aristocrats anoint me too as king?’

an3.13:2.7.eng: This is called a hopeful individual.

an3.13:3.1.eng: And what, mendicants, is an individual who has done away with hope?

an3.13:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, rājā hoti khattiyo muddhāvasitto.
an3.13:3.2.eng: It’s when a king has been anointed.

an3.13:3.4.eng: ‘They say that the aristocrats have anointed the aristocrat named so-and-so as king.’

an3.13:3.6.eng: ‘Oh, when will the aristocrats anoint me too as king?’

an3.13:3.8.pli: Yā hissa, bhikkhave, pubbe anabhisittassa abhisekāsā sā paṭippassaddhā.
an3.13:3.8.eng: Because the former hope he had to be anointed has now died down.

an3.13:3.9.eng: This is called an individual who has done away with hope.

an3.13:3.10.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmiṃ.
an3.13:3.10.eng: These are the three individuals found in the world.

an3.13:4.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tayo puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā bhikkhūsu.
an3.13:4.1.eng: In the same way, these three individuals are found among the mendicants.

an3.13:4.3.eng: The hopeless, the hopeful, and the one who has done away with hope.

an3.13:4.4.eng: And what, mendicants, is a hopeless individual?

an3.13:4.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo dussīlo hoti pāpadhammo asuci saṅkassarasamācāro paṭicchannakammanto assamaṇo samaṇapaṭiñño abrahmacārī brahmacāripaṭiñño antopūti avassuto kasambujāto.
an3.13:4.5.eng: It’s when an individual is unethical, of bad qualities, filthy, with suspicious behavior, underhand, no true ascetic or spiritual practitioner—though claiming to be one—rotten inside, festering, and depraved.

an3.13:4.7.pli: ‘itthannāmo kira bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī’ti.
an3.13:4.7.eng: ‘They say that the mendicant named so-and-so has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.’

an3.13:4.9.pli: ‘kudāssu nāma ahampi āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissāmī’ti.
an3.13:4.9.eng: ‘Oh, when will I too realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.’

an3.13:4.10.eng: This is called a hopeless individual.

an3.13:5.1.eng: And what, mendicants, is a hopeful individual?

an3.13:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sīlavā hoti kalyāṇadhammo.
an3.13:5.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, of good character.

an3.13:5.4.pli: ‘itthannāmo kira bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī’ti.
an3.13:5.4.eng: ‘They say that the mendicant named so-and-so has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.’

an3.13:5.6.pli: ‘kudāssu nāma ahampi āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissāmī’ti.
an3.13:5.6.eng: ‘Oh, when will I too realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.’

an3.13:5.7.eng: This is called a hopeful individual.

an3.13:6.1.eng: And what, mendicants, is an individual who has done away with hope?

an3.13:6.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu arahaṃ hoti khīṇāsavo.
an3.13:6.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant is a perfected one, who has ended all defilements.

an3.13:6.4.pli: ‘itthannāmo kira bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharatī’ti.
an3.13:6.4.eng: ‘They say that the mendicant named so-and-so has realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.’

an3.13:6.6.pli: ‘kudāssu nāma ahampi āsavānaṃ khayā …pe… sacchikatvā upasampajja viharissāmī’ti.
an3.13:6.6.eng: ‘Oh, when will I too realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life, and live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.’

an3.13:6.8.pli: Yā hissa, bhikkhave, pubbe avimuttassa vimuttāsā sā paṭippassaddhā.
an3.13:6.8.eng: Because the former hope they had to be freed has now died down.

an3.13:6.9.eng: This is called an individual who has done away with hope.

an3.13:6.10.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā bhikkhūsū”ti.
an3.13:6.10.eng: These are the three individuals found among the mendicants.”

an3.130:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā anuruddho yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṃ sammodi.
an3.130:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Anuruddha went up to Venerable Sāriputta, and exchanged greetings with him.

an3.130:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā anuruddho āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
an3.130:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to him:

an3.130:1.3.pli: “idhāhaṃ, āvuso sāriputta, dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena sahassaṃ lokaṃ olokemi.
an3.130:1.3.eng: “Here’s the thing, Reverend Sāriputta. With clairvoyance that is purified and surpasses the human, I survey the thousandfold galaxy.

an3.130:1.4.pli: Āraddhaṃ kho pana me vīriyaṃ asallīnaṃ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, passaddho kāyo asāraddho, samāhitaṃ cittaṃ ekaggaṃ.
an3.130:1.4.eng: My energy is roused up and unflagging, my mindfulness is established and lucid, my body is tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind is immersed in samādhi and unified.

an3.130:1.5.pli: Atha ca pana me nānupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuccatī”ti.
an3.130:1.5.eng: But my mind is not freed from the defilements by not grasping.”

an3.130:2.1.pli: “Yaṃ kho te, āvuso anuruddha, evaṃ hoti:

an3.130:2.2.pli: ‘ahaṃ dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena sahassaṃ lokaṃ volokemī’ti, idaṃ te mānasmiṃ.
an3.130:2.2.eng: ‘With clairvoyance that is purified and surpasses the human, I survey the thousandfold galaxy,’ that’s your conceit.

an3.130:2.3.pli: Yampi te, āvuso anuruddha, evaṃ hoti:

an3.130:2.4.pli: ‘āraddhaṃ kho pana me vīriyaṃ asallīnaṃ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, passaddho kāyo asāraddho, samāhitaṃ cittaṃ ekaggan’ti, idaṃ te uddhaccasmiṃ.
an3.130:2.4.eng: ‘My energy is roused up and unflagging, my mindfulness is established and lucid, my body is tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind is immersed in samādhi,’ that’s your restlessness.

an3.130:2.5.pli: Yampi te, āvuso anuruddha, evaṃ hoti:

an3.130:2.6.pli: ‘atha ca pana me nānupādāya āsavehi cittaṃ vimuccatī’ti, idaṃ te kukkuccasmiṃ.
an3.130:2.6.eng: ‘But my mind is not freed from the defilements by not grasping,’ that’s your remorse.

an3.130:2.7.pli: Sādhu vatāyasmā anuruddho ime tayo dhamme pahāya, ime tayo dhamme amanasikaritvā amatāya dhātuyā cittaṃ upasaṃharatū”ti.
an3.130:2.7.eng: It would be good to give up these three things. Ignore them and apply your mind to freedom from death.”

an3.130:3.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā anuruddho aparena samayena ime tayo dhamme pahāya, ime tayo dhamme amanasikaritvā amatāya dhātuyā cittaṃ upasaṃhari.
an3.130:3.1.eng: After some time Anuruddha gave up these three things. Ignoring them, he applied his mind to freedom from death.

an3.130:3.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā anuruddho eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
an3.130:3.2.eng: Then Anuruddha, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

an3.130:3.3.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
an3.130:3.3.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

an3.130:3.4.pli: Aññataro ca panāyasmā anuruddho arahataṃ ahosīti.
an3.130:3.4.eng: And Venerable Anuruddha became one of the perfected.

an3.131:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, three things are conveyed under cover, not in the open.

an3.131:1.3.pli: Mātugāmo, bhikkhave, paṭicchanno āvahati, no vivaṭo;
an3.131:1.3.eng: Females are married with a veil, not unveiled.

an3.131:1.4.pli: brāhmaṇānaṃ, bhikkhave, mantā paṭicchannā āvahanti, no vivaṭā;
an3.131:1.4.eng: Brahmin hymns are conveyed under cover, not openly.

an3.131:1.5.pli: micchādiṭṭhi, bhikkhave, paṭicchannā āvahati, no vivaṭā.
an3.131:1.5.eng: Wrong view is conveyed under cover, not in the open.

an3.131:1.6.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi paṭicchannāni āvahanti, no vivaṭāni.
an3.131:1.6.eng: These three things are conveyed under cover, not in the open.

an3.131:2.1.pli: Tīṇimāni, bhikkhave, vivaṭāni virocanti, no paṭicchannāni.
an3.131:2.1.eng: Three things shine in the open, not under cover.

an3.131:2.3.pli: Candamaṇḍalaṃ, bhikkhave, vivaṭaṃ virocati, no paṭicchannaṃ;
an3.131:2.3.eng: The moon shines in the open, not under cover.

an3.131:2.4.pli: sūriyamaṇḍalaṃ, bhikkhave, vivaṭaṃ virocati, no paṭicchannaṃ;
an3.131:2.4.eng: The sun shines in the open, not under cover.

an3.131:2.5.pli: tathāgatappavedito dhammavinayo, bhikkhave, vivaṭo virocati, no paṭicchanno.
an3.131:2.5.eng: The teaching and training proclaimed by a Realized One shine in the open, not under cover.

an3.131:2.6.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, tīṇi vivaṭāni virocanti, no paṭicchannānī”ti.
an3.131:2.6.eng: These three things shine in the open, not under cover.”

an3.132:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, these three individuals are found in the world.

an3.132:1.3.pli: Pāsāṇalekhūpamo puggalo, pathavilekhūpamo puggalo, udakalekhūpamo puggalo.
an3.132:1.3.eng: An individual like a line drawn in stone, an individual like a line drawn in sand, and an individual like a line drawn in water.

an3.132:1.4.eng: And who is the individual like a line drawn in stone?

an3.132:1.5.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo abhiṇhaṃ kujjhati.
an3.132:1.5.eng: It’s an individual who is often angry,

an3.132:1.6.pli: So ca khvassa kodho dīgharattaṃ anuseti.
an3.132:1.6.eng: and their anger lingers for a long time.

an3.132:1.7.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, pāsāṇe lekhā na khippaṃ lujjati vātena vā udakena vā, ciraṭṭhitikā hoti;
an3.132:1.7.eng: It’s like a line drawn in stone, which isn’t quickly worn away by wind and water, but lasts for a long time.

an3.132:1.8.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco puggalo abhiṇhaṃ kujjhati.
an3.132:1.8.eng: In the same way, an individual is often angry,

an3.132:1.9.pli: So ca khvassa kodho dīgharattaṃ anuseti.
an3.132:1.9.eng: and their anger lingers for a long time.

an3.132:1.10.eng: This is called an individual like a line drawn in stone.

an3.132:2.1.eng: And who is the individual like a line drawn in sand?

an3.132:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo abhiṇhaṃ kujjhati.
an3.132:2.2.eng: It’s an individual who is often angry,

an3.132:2.3.pli: So ca khvassa kodho na dīgharattaṃ anuseti.
an3.132:2.3.eng: but their anger doesn’t linger long.

an3.132:2.4.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, pathaviyā lekhā khippaṃ lujjati vātena vā udakena vā, na ciraṭṭhitikā hoti;
an3.132:2.4.eng: It’s like a line drawn in sand, which is quickly worn away by wind and water, and doesn’t last long.

an3.132:2.5.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco puggalo abhiṇhaṃ kujjhati.
an3.132:2.5.eng: In the same way, an individual is often angry,

an3.132:2.6.pli: So ca khvassa kodho na dīgharattaṃ anuseti.
an3.132:2.6.eng: but their anger doesn’t linger long.

an3.132:2.7.eng: This is called an individual like a line drawn in sand.

an3.132:3.1.eng: And who is the individual like a line drawn in water?

an3.132:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco puggalo āgāḷhenapi vuccamāno pharusenapi vuccamāno amanāpenapi vuccamāno sandhiyatimeva saṃsandatimeva sammodatimeva.
an3.132:3.2.eng: It’s an individual who, though spoken to by someone in a rough, harsh, and disagreeable manner, still stays in touch, interacts with, and greets them.

an3.132:3.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, udake lekhā khippaṃyeva paṭivigacchati, na ciraṭṭhitikā hoti;
an3.132:3.3.eng: It’s like a line drawn in water, which vanishes right away, and doesn’t last long.

an3.132:3.4.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, idhekacco puggalo āgāḷhenapi vuccamāno pharusenapi vuccamāno amanāpenapi vuccamāno sandhiyatimeva saṃsandatimeva sammodatimeva.
an3.132:3.4.eng: In the same way, an individual, though spoken to by someone in a rough, harsh, and disagreeable manner, still stays in touch, interacts with, and greets them.

an3.132:3.5.eng: This is called an individual like a line drawn in water.

an3.132:3.6.pli: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tayo puggalā santo saṃvijjamānā lokasmin”ti.
an3.132:3.6.eng: These are the three individuals found in the world.”

an3.133:1.1.pli: “Tīhi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato yodhājīvo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅganteva saṅkhyaṃ gacchati.
an3.133:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a warrior with three factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and is reckoned as a factor of kingship.

an3.133:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, yodhājīvo dūre pātī ca hoti akkhaṇavedhī ca mahato ca kāyassa padāletā.
an3.133:1.3.eng: He’s a long-distance shooter, a marksman, one who shatters large objects.

an3.133:1.4.pli: Imehi, kho, bhikkhave, tīhi aṅgehi samannāgato yodhājīvo rājāraho hoti rājabhoggo, rañño aṅganteva saṅkhyaṃ gacchati.
an3.133:1.4.eng: A warrior with these three factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and is reckoned as a factor of kingship.

an3.133:1.5.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, tīhi aṅgehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassa.
an3.133:1.5.eng: In the same way, a mendicant with three factors is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.

an3.133:1.7.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dūre pātī ca hoti akkhaṇavedhī ca mahato ca kāyassa padāletā.
an3.133:1.7.eng: They’re a long-distance shooter, a marksman, and one who shatters large objects.

an3.133:2.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dūre pātī hoti?
an3.133:2.1.eng: And how is a mendicant a long-distance shooter?

an3.133:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yaṃ kiñci rūpaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ rūpaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
an3.133:2.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant truly sees any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

an3.133:2.3.pli: Yā kāci vedanā atītānāgatapaccuppannā ajjhattā vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikā vā sukhumā vā hīnā vā paṇītā vā yā dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ vedanaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
an3.133:2.3.eng: They truly see any kind of feeling at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all feeling—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

an3.133:2.4.pli: Yā kāci saññā atītānāgatapaccuppannā ajjhattā vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikā vā sukhumā vā hīnā vā paṇītā vā yā dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ saññaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
an3.133:2.4.eng: They truly see any kind of perception at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all perception—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

an3.133:2.5.pli: Ye keci saṅkhārā atītānāgatapaccuppannā ajjhattā vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikā vā sukhumā vā hīnā vā paṇītā vā ye dūre santike vā, sabbe saṅkhāre: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
an3.133:2.5.eng: They truly see any kind of choices at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all choices—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

an3.133:2.6.pli: Yaṃ kiñci viññāṇaṃ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṃ ajjhattaṃ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṃ vā sukhumaṃ vā hīnaṃ vā paṇītaṃ vā yaṃ dūre santike vā, sabbaṃ viññāṇaṃ: ‘netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya passati.
an3.133:2.6.eng: They truly see any kind of consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near, all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

an3.133:2.7.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu dūre pātī hoti.
an3.133:2.7.eng: That’s how a mendicant is a long-distance shooter.

an3.133:3.1.eng: And how is a mendicant a marksman?

an3.133:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti; ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti; ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti; ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ pajānāti.
an3.133:3.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.

an3.133:3.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu akkhaṇavedhī hoti.
an3.133:3.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant is a marksman.

an3.133:4.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu mahato kāyassa padāletā hoti?
an3.133:4.1.eng: And how does a mendicant shatter large objects?

an3.133:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu mahantaṃ avijjākkhandhaṃ padāleti.
an3.133:4.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant shatters the great mass of ignorance.

an3.133:4.3.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu mahato kāyassa padāletā hoti.
an3.133:4.3.eng: That’s how a mendicant shatters large objects.

an3.133:4.4.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu āhuneyyo hoti …pe… anuttaraṃ puññakkhettaṃ lokassā”ti.
an3.133:4.4.eng: A mendicant with these three qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.”

an3.134:1.3.pli: Ukkācitavinītā parisā, paṭipucchāvinītā parisā, yāvatāvinītā parisā—
an3.134:1.3.eng: An assembly educated in fancy talk, an assembly educated in questioning, and an assembly educated to the fullest extent.

an3.135:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, you should associate with a friend who has three factors.

an3.135:1.3.pli: Duddadaṃ dadāti, dukkaraṃ karoti, dukkhamaṃ khamati—
an3.135:1.3.eng: They give what is hard to give, they do what is hard to do, and they bear what is hard to bear.

an3.135:1.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi aṅgehi samannāgato mitto sevitabbo”ti.
an3.135:1.4.eng: You should associate with a friend who has these three factors.”

an3.136:1.1.pli: “Uppādā vā, bhikkhave, tathāgatānaṃ anuppādā vā tathāgatānaṃ, ṭhitāva sā dhātu dhammaṭṭhitatā dhammaniyāmatā.
an3.136:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, whether Realized Ones arise or not, this law of nature persists, this regularity of natural principles, this surety of natural principles:

an3.136:1.3.eng: A Realized One awakens to this and comprehends it,

an3.136:1.4.pli: Abhisambujjhitvā abhisametvā ācikkhati deseti paññāpeti paṭṭhapeti vivarati vibhajati uttānīkaroti:
an3.136:1.4.eng: then he explains, teaches, asserts, establishes, clarifies, analyzes, and reveals it:

an3.136:1.6.pli: Uppādā vā, bhikkhave, tathāgatānaṃ anuppādā vā tathāgatānaṃ ṭhitāva sā dhātu dhammaṭṭhitatā dhammaniyāmatā.
an3.136:1.6.eng: Whether Realized Ones arise or not, this law of nature persists, this regularity of natural principles, this surety of natural principles:

an3.136:1.8.eng: A Realized One awakens to this and comprehends it,

an3.136:1.9.pli: Abhisambujjhitvā abhisametvā ācikkhati deseti paññāpeti paṭṭhapeti vivarati vibhajati uttānīkaroti:
an3.136:1.9.eng: then he explains, teaches, asserts, establishes, clarifies, analyzes, and reveals it:

an3.136:1.11.pli: Uppādā vā, bhikkhave, tathāgatānaṃ anuppādā vā tathāgatānaṃ ṭhitāva sā dhātu dhammaṭṭhitatā dhammaniyāmatā.
an3.136:1.11.eng: Whether Realized Ones arise or not, this law of nature persists, this regularity of natural principles, this surety of natural principles:

an3.136:1.13.eng: A Realized One awakens to this and comprehends it,

an3.136:1.14.pli: Abhisambujjhitvā abhisametvā ācikkhati deseti paññāpeti paṭṭhapeti vivarati vibhajati uttānīkaroti:
an3.136:1.14.eng: then he explains, teaches, asserts, establishes, clarifies, analyzes, and reveals it:

an3.137:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yāni kānici tantāvutānaṃ vatthānaṃ, kesakambalo tesaṃ paṭikiṭṭho akkhāyati.
an3.137:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a hair blanket is said to be the worst kind of woven cloth.

an3.137:1.2.pli: Kesakambalo, bhikkhave, sīte sīto, uṇhe uṇho, dubbaṇṇo, duggandho, dukkhasamphasso.
an3.137:1.2.eng: It’s cold in the cold, hot in the heat, ugly, smelly, and unpleasant to touch.

an3.137:1.3.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, yāni kānici puthusamaṇabrāhmaṇavādānaṃ makkhalivādo tesaṃ paṭikiṭṭho akkhāyati.
an3.137:1.3.eng: In the same way, the teaching of the bamboo-staffed ascetic is said to be the worst of all the doctrines of the various ascetics and brahmins.

an3.137:2.1.eng: The bamboo-staffed ascetic, that futile man, has this doctrine and view:

an3.137:2.2.eng: ‘There is no power in deeds, action, or energy.’

an3.137:2.3.pli: Yepi te, bhikkhave, ahesuṃ atītamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, tepi bhagavanto kammavādā ceva ahesuṃ kiriyavādā ca vīriyavādā ca.
an3.137:2.3.eng: Those who were perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas in the past also taught the efficacy of deeds, action, and energy.

an3.137:2.4.eng: But the bamboo-staffed ascetic opposes them by saying:

an3.137:2.5.eng: ‘There is no power in deeds, action, or energy.’

an3.137:2.6.pli: Yepi te, bhikkhave, bhavissanti anāgatamaddhānaṃ arahanto sammāsambuddhā, tepi bhagavanto kammavādā ceva bhavissanti kiriyavādā ca vīriyavādā ca.
an3.137:2.6.eng: Those who will be perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas in the future will also teach the efficacy of deeds, action, and energy.

an3.137:2.7.eng: But the bamboo-staffed ascetic opposes them by saying:

an3.137:2.8.eng: ‘There is no power in deeds, action, or energy.’

an3.137:2.9.pli: Ahampi, bhikkhave, etarahi arahaṃ sammāsambuddho kammavādo ceva kiriyavādo ca vīriyavādo ca.
an3.137:2.9.eng: I too, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha in the present, teach the efficacy of deeds, action, and energy.

an3.137:2.10.eng: But the bamboo-staffed ascetic opposes me by saying:

an3.137:2.11.eng: ‘There is no power in deeds, action, or energy.’

an3.137:3.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, nadīmukhe khippaṃ uḍḍeyya bahūnaṃ macchānaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya anayāya byasanāya;
an3.137:3.1.eng: It’s like a trap set at the mouth of a river, which would bring harm, suffering, calamity, and disaster for many fish.

an3.137:3.2.pli: evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, makkhali moghapuriso manussakhippaṃ maññe loke uppanno bahūnaṃ sattānaṃ ahitāya dukkhāya anayāya byasanāyā”ti.
an3.137:3.2.eng: In the same way that futile man the bamboo-staffed ascetic is a trap for humans, it seems to me. He has come into the world for the harm, suffering, calamity, and disaster of many beings.”

an3.138:1.3.eng: Accomplishment in faith, ethics, and wisdom.

an3.139:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are three kinds of growth.

an3.139:1.3.eng: Growth in faith, ethics, and wisdom.

an3.139:1.4.eng: These are the three kinds of growth.”

an3.14:1.1.pli: “Yopi so, bhikkhave, rājā cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā sopi na arājakaṃ cakkaṃ vattetī”ti.
an3.14:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, even a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king, does not wield power without having their own king.”

an3.14:1.2.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an3.14:1.2.eng: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha:

an3.14:1.3.pli: “ko pana, bhante, rañño cakkavattissa dhammikassa dhammarañño rājā”ti?
an3.14:1.3.eng: “But who is the king of the wheel-turning monarch, the just and principled king?”

an3.14:1.4.eng: “It is principle, monk,” said the Buddha.

an3.14:1.5.pli: “idha, bhikkhu, rājā cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā dhammaṃyeva nissāya dhammaṃ sakkaronto dhammaṃ garuṃ karonto dhammaṃ apacāyamāno dhammaddhajo dhammaketu dhammādhipateyyo dhammikaṃ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidahati antojanasmiṃ.
an3.14:1.5.eng: “Monk, a wheel-turning monarch provides just protection and security for his court, relying only on principle—honoring, respecting, and venerating principle, having principle as his flag, banner, and authority.

an3.14:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhu, rājā cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā dhammaṃyeva nissāya dhammaṃ sakkaronto dhammaṃ garuṃ karonto dhammaṃ apacāyamāno dhammaddhajo dhammaketu dhammādhipateyyo dhammikaṃ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidahati khattiyesu, anuyantesu, balakāyasmiṃ, brāhmaṇagahapatikesu, negamajānapadesu, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu, migapakkhīsu.
an3.14:2.1.eng: He provides just protection and security for his aristocrats, vassals, troops, brahmins and householders, people of town and country, ascetics and brahmins, beasts and birds.

an3.14:2.2.pli: Sa kho so bhikkhu rājā cakkavattī dhammiko dhammarājā dhammaṃyeva nissāya dhammaṃ sakkaronto dhammaṃ garuṃ karonto dhammaṃ apacāyamāno dhammaddhajo dhammaketu dhammādhipateyyo dhammikaṃ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidahitvā antojanasmiṃ, dhammikaṃ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidahitvā khattiyesu …pe… anuyantesu, balakāyasmiṃ, brāhmaṇagahapatikesu, negamajānapadesu, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu, migapakkhīsu, dhammeneva cakkaṃ vatteti.
an3.14:2.2.eng: When he has done this, he wields power only in a principled manner.

an3.14:2.3.pli: Taṃ hoti cakkaṃ appaṭivattiyaṃ kenaci manussabhūtena paccatthikena pāṇinā.
an3.14:2.3.eng: And this power cannot be undermined by any human enemy.

an3.14:3.1.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhu, tathāgato arahaṃ sammāsambuddho dhammiko dhammarājā dhammaṃyeva nissāya dhammaṃ sakkaronto dhammaṃ garuṃ karonto dhammaṃ apacāyamāno dhammaddhajo dhammaketu dhammādhipateyyo dhammikaṃ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidahati kāyakammasmiṃ:
an3.14:3.1.eng: In the same way, monk, a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, a just and principled king, provides just protection and security regarding bodily actions, relying only on principle—honoring, respecting, and venerating principle, having principle as his flag, banner, and authority.

an3.14:3.2.pli: ‘evarūpaṃ kāyakammaṃ sevitabbaṃ, evarūpaṃ kāyakammaṃ na sevitabban’ti.
an3.14:3.2.eng: ‘This kind of bodily action should be cultivated. This kind of bodily action should not be cultivated.’

an3.14:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhu, tathāgato arahaṃ sammāsambuddho dhammiko dhammarājā dhammaṃyeva nissāya dhammaṃ sakkaronto dhammaṃ garuṃ karonto dhammaṃ apacāyamāno dhammaddhajo dhammaketu dhammādhipateyyo dhammikaṃ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidahati vacīkammasmiṃ:
an3.14:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a Realized One … provides just protection and security regarding verbal actions, saying:

an3.14:4.2.pli: ‘evarūpaṃ vacīkammaṃ sevitabbaṃ, evarūpaṃ vacīkammaṃ na sevitabban’ti …pe… manokammasmiṃ:
an3.14:4.2.eng: ‘This kind of verbal action should be cultivated. This kind of verbal action should not be cultivated.’ … And regarding mental actions:

an3.14:4.3.pli: ‘evarūpaṃ manokammaṃ sevitabbaṃ, evarūpaṃ manokammaṃ na sevitabban’ti.
an3.14:4.3.eng: ‘This kind of mental action should be cultivated. This kind of mental action should not be cultivated.’

an3.14:5.1.pli: Sa kho so, bhikkhu, tathāgato arahaṃ sammāsambuddho dhammiko dhammarājā dhammaṃyeva nissāya dhammaṃ sakkaronto dhammaṃ garuṃ karonto dhammaṃ apacāyamāno dhammaddhajo dhammaketu dhammādhipateyyo dhammikaṃ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidahitvā kāyakammasmiṃ, dhammikaṃ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidahitvā vacīkammasmiṃ, dhammikaṃ rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidahitvā manokammasmiṃ, dhammeneva anuttaraṃ dhammacakkaṃ pavatteti.
an3.14:5.1.eng: And when a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha has provided just protection and security regarding actions of body, speech, and mind, he rolls forth the supreme Wheel of Dhamma.

an3.14:5.2.pli: Taṃ hoti cakkaṃ appaṭivattiyaṃ samaṇena vā brāhmaṇena vā devena vā mārena vā brahmunā vā kenaci vā lokasmin”ti.
an3.14:5.2.eng: And that wheel cannot be rolled back by any ascetic or brahmin or god or Māra or divinity or by anyone in the world.”
